item.title: Holiday surge expected after travel rules change
item.description: Travel agents report a rise in bookings after the amber list is scrapped and testing rules are eased.

item.title: Aukus: France recalls envoys amid security pact row
item.description: The "exceptional decision" follows a pact between Australia, the US and UK, which scuppered a French deal.

item.title: Gas price rises prompt urgent government talks
item.description: There are concerns the high price of wholesale gas could have a far-reaching impact on the economy.

item.title: Afghanistan: US admits Kabul drone strike killed civilians
item.description: An inquiry finds the strike, days before the US pullout, killed 10 members of a family - not militants.

item.title: Covid-19: Holiday surge expected and calculator that spots most at risk
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Saturday morning.

item.title: Robert Durst convicted: US millionaire found guilty of first-degree murder
item.description: Durst was convicted of killing his best friend Susan Berman in 2000, and is likely to die in prison.

item.title: More than half of Department for Transport cars still diesel
item.description: Figures show the department in charge of the transition away from diesel still relies on the fuel.

item.title: Unpaid state pension: 'I'm disgusted by delays'
item.description: Thousands of people who have turned 66 have not been paid their state pensions and they are furious.

item.title: Ronapreve: 'Most vulnerable' to get new Covid drug next week
item.description: Antibody therapy Ronapreve, given to Donald Trump, will be given to eligible NHS patients in hospital.

item.title: Covid calculator spots people vulnerable despite jabs
item.description: An online tool could help doctors identify those who would benefit from boosters or early therapy.

item.title: Ruling limiting under-16s puberty blockers overturned
item.description: The appeal decision reverses a High Court ruling that under-16s would struggle to give informed consent.

item.title: Brazil legend Pele says he is 'recovering very well' after surgery
item.description: Brazil legend Pele says he is "recovering well" from a recent operation after briefly being readmitted to intensive care.

item.title: The papers: Holiday bookings 'surge' and gas price rises
item.description: A boom in holiday bookings following a change to England's travel rules is among the stories leading the papers.

item.title: Ros Atkins On… the ethics of Covid booster jabs
item.description: Ros Atkins looks at the ethics of Western countries rolling out Covid booster jabs while millions globally remain unvaccinated.

item.title: Afghanistan: The escape of the whirling dancer
item.description: How the only female whirling dancer in Afghanistan made it out of Kabul.

item.title: Planes turned into graffiti canvasses by street artist
item.description: Street artist Jim Vision had an idea for what to do with planes that have ended their flying days.

item.title: Week in pictures: 11 - 17 September 2021
item.description: A selection of powerful images from all over the globe, taken this week.

item.title: Thailand Covid: Idle taxis used to grow food for out-of-work drivers
item.description: With Thailand's capital under tight Covid restrictions, taxis are being repurposed to grow food.

item.title: 'It's still sinking in!' - Raducanu on winning the US Open
item.description: British teenager Emma Raducanu tells BBC Breakfast about the "whirlwind" experience of winning the US Open.

item.title: Three Chinese astronauts return to Earth after 90 days in space
item.description: The three men make a safe return after 90 days in space - China's longest ever crewed mission.

item.title: California fires: General Sherman and other sequoias given blankets
item.description: Fire-resistant blankets protect General Sherman and other sequoias as a California blaze closes in.

item.title: Strictly Come Dancing: 15 things we learned from the stars of 2021
item.description: A round-up of 15 things we learned from this year's Strictly Come Dancing celebrities.

item.title: Climate change: Should green campaigners put more pressure on China to slash emissions?
item.description: UK activists have protested on the M25, but should they instead be picketing China's embassy?

item.title: 'There’s security but no money': Afghans settle into life under Taliban rule
item.description: In Mazar-i-Sharif, former army pilots are flying Taliban around and families are selling possessions for food.

item.title: Lib Dem conference: Sir Ed Davey gambles on targeting Tories
item.description: The Lib Dems are facing a battle to get heard at their online conference but they are in good spirits.

item.title: German elections: How Angela Merkel changed her country
item.description: Young people have never known another leader, and many worry for the future as old certainties shift.

item.title: Muriel Gardiner: The heiress who saved countless lives
item.description: Muriel Gardiner's courage fighting fascism in Austria inspired an Oscar-winning film. Who was she?

item.title: Keira Bell case: What are puberty blockers?
item.description: Doctors can now judge whether under-16s can give informed consent to taking puberty blockers.

item.title: US politician Nancy Pelosi heads to Chorley, Lancashire for G7 summit
item.description: The Lancashire town is hosting a meeting of presiding officers - including the US Speaker of the House.

item.title: Aukus: Defence pact an awkward wake-up call for Europe
item.description: As Australia, the UK and the US seal a security pact, the EU does not quite know where to look.

item.title: The big problem of building waste and how to tackle it
item.description: How better technology and regulation could cut the waste generated by the construction industry.

item.title: England's 8-0 win was 'OK' - Wiegman gives glimpse of Lionesses' future
item.description: Sarina Wiegman's England tenure started with an 8-0 thrashing of North Macedonia but she still demanded more.

item.title: Newcastle boss Bruce battles on after 'difficult' night
item.description: Newcastle boss Steve Bruce admits he faced a "difficult" night against Leeds when fans turned on him.

item.title: Derby County: Championship club file notice to appoint administrators
item.description: Derby County will go into administration amid continued financial problems and face a 12-point deduction.

item.title: Lozowski kicks Saracens to win at Bristol on Premiership return
item.description: Fly-half Alex Lozowski kicks 21 points as promoted Saracens win 26-9 at Bristol Bears on their return to the Premiership.

item.title: Man City: 'I won't apologise' for fans comments, says Pep Guardiola
item.description: Manager Pep Guardiola says he "will not apologise" for calling on more Manchester City fans to attend their Premier League game with Southampton.

item.title: Newcastle United 1-1 Leeds United: Steve Bruce 'delighted' with fight to get draw
item.description: Newcastle United manager Steve Bruce says he was "delighted" with his side's response to get a draw against Leeds United.

item.title: T20 Blast Finals Day: Who will be victorious in all-southern affair?
item.description: Sussex Sharks, Hampshire Hawks, Somerset and Kent Spitfires head to Edgbaston in a bid to be crowned T20 Blast champions.

item.title: What are the travel rules now and for half term?
item.description: The rules on foreign travel to and from England are being simplified.

item.title: What are the travel rules for Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots?
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Covid: People are vaccinated - so why are there so many cases?
item.description: More than four out of five UK adults are now fully vaccinated, but daily case rates remain high.

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid passports: How do I get one and when will I need it?
item.description: People in Scotland will need to be fully vaccinated to go to clubs, sporting events and concerts.

item.title: Long Covid: What is it and what are the symptoms?
item.description: Significant numbers have had long-term problems after recovering from the original infection.

item.title: Covid rules: What's in England's 'Winter Plan'?
item.description: Lockdown rules have changed across the UK, but some restrictions remain in place.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings?
item.description: Face coverings could become a legal requirement in England again if the NHS struggles this winter.

item.title: Flu jab 2021: Who’s eligible for a free vaccine?
item.description: This year's roll out has expanded in an attempt to shield against a double whammy of flu and Covid.

item.title: Is it safe to vaccinate our child? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about vaccinating 12-15 year-olds, the booster vaccine and other topics.

item.title: Hushpuppi - the Instagram influencer and international fraudster
item.description: How Nigerian Ramon Abbas went from a romance scammer to a so-called "Billionaire Gucci Master".

item.title: ‘Havana syndrome ’ and the mystery of the microwaves
item.description: The BBC investigates a mystery illness dubbed "Havana syndrome" that has affected American diplomats and spies.

item.title: 'The near-death experience that made me a top musician'
item.description: When Tony Kofi had a near-fatal accident, he had a vision of himself playing a musical instrument. It would change his life forever.

item.title: Chaos and confusion: The frenzied final hours of the Afghan government
item.description: Through interviews with insiders, BBC News has pieced together an account of how Afghanistan’s government unravelled.

item.title: 'I studied law in jail - now I want to change the system'
item.description: LaTonya Myers spent nine months in jail because she couldn’t afford bail - now she's helping others facing the same challenge.
